messages.text: Hello everyone! I'm Vighnesh, a drummer of 8 years  and I was going through projects when I found automated music generation. I have read the resources and found it to be right my my alley. I also learnt the basics of Flux and just wrote a simple model in it. I would like to know more as to how I can start working towards contributing to this project. I would love to connect to anyone who can point me in the right direction! I'm looking forward!

messages.text:
Greetings everyone! I'm a senior year UG at IIT Kanpur, India aiming at this year's GSoC & JSoC. Came across Julia for performing large-scale simulations and loved it! I've sound background in Numerical Methods, Linear algebra & DEs and am interested in contributing to GenericLinearAlgebra.jl; TaylorModels.jl & Discretizations of PDEs.
Please tag the potential mentors. Thanks in advance :)

messages.text:
Hi guys. My name is Som Tambe, and I am also from IIT Kanpur coincidentially. I am an undergraduate here majoring in Aerospace Engineering. I like GPUs and am acquainted with writing kernels in CUDA. Right now I have explored CUDA.jl and it is really a superb abstraction over CUDA C++ given the absolutely lovely performance I get over it compared to CUDA C++ (weighing in the abstractions).
I would love to work this summer making GPU kernels in Julia for GSOC.
Hope everyone reading this has a great day! Cheers!

messages.text:
Hi everyone.
I'm Sambhaw, a UG student from IIT Kharagpur, looking forward to contributing in Mathematical libaries, Deep Learning and Natural Language Processing in Julia. 
I'm highly intrigued by theoretical Computer Science and AI given their high momentum in these times.
Currently, I am exploring the possibilities in JuliaText and Flux (supplemented with minor patches). 
Feel free to discuss any new ideas. I am decently equipped with knowledge in planning, DL and RL. 
I'm looking forward to GSOC and JSoC this year. 
I would love to contribute to and interact with this wonderful community. 
Have a good day! :smile:

Hello people.
I am Harsh , I am a student pursuing my  bachelors in computer engineering. I am interested in Machine Learning algorithms. I came across Julia a couple months back and want to be part of its community. I want to contribute towards this fast growing language.
Currently I am going through all the documentations and exploring the libraries of Julia. I would highly appreciate if someone could give some guidance points about what should I learn and how should I proceed to explore and make implement my own ideas here.

messages.text:
Hey everyone! I'm Atreya, currently pursuing my Bachelor's in Electronics and Communications Engineering. I've always been really interested in scientific computing, and I'd love to start my open source journey with Julia! My primary fields of interest are Machine Learning (more towards the deep learning bit but I like statistical modeling as well), and Signal Processing (Digital Speech and Audio Signals in particular)!
I've been learning Julia and I feel more comfortable with it now. I'd like to start contributing to existing issues.
I had a question: Do packages like JuliaDSP fall under the Julia umbrella (in terms of the org maintaining the package), or is it considered to be a completely separate entity?

messages.text:
Hi everyone! I'm José Joaquín Zubieta Rico. I'm a student of a Bachelor program in Computer Science at the University of Guanajuato (Universidad de Guanajuato) and CIMAT (Research Institute of Mathematics) in México. I've been using Julia for a couple of years as part of a research project and for work at my school.
Love the language, the environment and the community around it. I'm really interested in contributing to an open source project and I think the Julia ecosystem is a really nice fit giving my area of study and interest (scientific computing in general, but specific in machine learning, numerical methods, and a hobby reading about programming language theory, HPC and compilers).
I would really like if someone could give me mentoring and guidance on the ecosystem, the language and how to get more involved, solve issues and contribute with new projects and ideas. Really exited to be able to contribute! :conga_parrot: :smile:

Hi everyone, This is Shivanshu, a sophomore at IIT Kanpur. I've used julia in the past, actually explored it because i wanted to learn some cool new language XD. Now, I'd like to take my chance contributing to it. I'm mostly interested in flux,jl
So, I was wondering if it's okay if i go ahead and try to implement some of the functions as stated in <https://github.com/FluxML/Flux.jl/issues/1431|1431>? I'm just starting out in the Julia Community, so I'd really appreciate if anyone can guide me.
Thanks in advance.

I have contributed in past to sciml(with the website's base,transfer of data),juliamusic and currently working on JuliaImages for some time now.

messages.text:
Hi Everyone!

I'm a 5th year student studying Math and Computer Science at Simon Fraser University, and will be starting my PhD in Computer Science there in the Fall. My main research interest is Safe RL but I'm also interested in numerical analysis.

I've been thinking of a way to spend my summer and thought it would be excellent to start to contribute to open source projects, seeing how I use them every day.

After looking through the listed projects, I'm super interested in either "Improvements to Neural and Universal Differential Equations" or "Discretization of partial differential equations" and would be grateful to talk to one of the mentors for either of the projects.

messages.text:
Hello, I'm a second year PhD student in the Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering Department at Johns Hopkins University.
My work is focused on applications of machine learning to accelerate molecule design. I’m interested in contributing as a part of the Google Summer of Code because of how Julia is geared towards scientific computing. I have taken part in developing a beginnner-level course in Python in my department, so as to make programming available for scientists in general. I think Julia could also be a great tool for this purpose and would like to be a part of its development.
I am interested in the DeepChem.jl development project, as it is an area that I hope to further explore going forward in my research career.
I am also interested in the DFTK.jl development projects because the idea of using automatic differentiation for DFT seems fascinating and I would like to try my hand at trying to make it work.
I hope I get the chance to contribute and would appreciate any pointers about making a competitive application!

elements.text:
Hello, I'm a second year PhD student in the Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering Department at Johns Hopkins University.
My work is focused on applications of machine learning to accelerate molecule design. I’m interested in contributing as a part of the Google Summer of Code because of how Julia is geared towards scientific computing. I have taken part in developing a beginnner-level course in Python in my department, so as to make programming available for scientists in general. I think Julia could also be a great tool for this purpose and would like to be a part of its development.
I am interested in the DeepChem.jl development project, as it is an area that I hope to further explore going forward in my research career.
I am also interested in the DFTK.jl development projects because the idea of using automatic differentiation for DFT seems fascinating and I would like to try my hand at trying to make it work.
I hope I get the chance to contribute and would appreciate any pointers about making a competitive application!

messages.text:
Hello all! I'm Sanjan, a final year Engineering undergrad (M.Eng year) at the University of Cambridge. I've been working on a Julia open-source library in the materials domain for about a year now as part of my Master's project, and I'm quite keen on continuing Julia development as part of JSoc this year. I've narrowed down a few of the listed projects that I want to apply for, but before that I express my interests in those, I had a few general questions about projects themselves!

1. Is it necessary to have some working experience with the library that the JSoc project is based on before applying? 
2. Some projects say they need reasonable experience of Julia from the applicant - what might be the best way to judge if you have that? 
Any inputs here appreciated!

elements.text: Hello all! I'm Sanjan, a final year Engineering undergrad (M.Eng year) at the University of Cambridge. I've been working on a Julia open-source library in the materials domain for about a year now as part of my Master's project, and I'm quite keen on continuing Julia development as part of JSoc this year. I've narrowed down a few of the listed projects that I want to apply for, but before that I express my interests in those, I had a few general questions about projects themselves!
Is it necessary to have some working experience with the library that the JSoc project is based on before applying?
Some projects say they need reasonable experience of Julia from the applicant - what might be the best way to judge if you have that?
Any inputs here appreciated!

messages.text:
Hello, I'm Emre. Currently I'm pursuing a masters degree at Koc University. I'm a full time student at COSBILAB. My lab works on computational structural biology, and my research topic is fast structural alignment of proteins with hashing methods. I'm developing the algorithm with Julia, using different packages from BioJulia.jl, and the algorithm itself.

My major is Data Science at Koc University, and I took several classes related with AI/ML/DL. Two of those classes are taught with purely Julia, using the Deep Learning package Knet.jl by Deniz Yuret himself.
This summer I would like to participate one of the available projects, I checked some of the projects and there are several interesting ones. What should I do further this point? I would like to participate one of the Reinforcement Learning or Deep Learning projects, or if you are open to it; I would also consider something about BioJulia.jl too.

Even writing to the community is exciting for me, I hope we can improve ourselves while developing something beneficial to this great community too!

elements.text:
Hello, I'm Emre. Currently I'm pursuing a masters degree at Koc University. I'm a full time student at COSBILAB. My lab works on computational structural biology, and my research topic is fast structural alignment of proteins with hashing methods. I'm developing the algorithm with Julia, using different packages from BioJulia.jl, and the algorithm itself.

My major is Data Science at Koc University, and I took several classes related with AI/ML/DL. Two of those classes are taught with purely Julia, using the Deep Learning package Knet.jl by Deniz Yuret himself.
This summer I would like to participate one of the available projects, I checked some of the projects and there are several interesting ones. What should I do further this point? I would like to participate one of the Reinforcement Learning or Deep Learning projects, or if you are open to it; I would also consider something about BioJulia.jl too.

Even writing to the community is exciting for me, I hope we can improve ourselves while developing something beneficial to this great community too!

elements.text: Hi Jameson, I want to apply for this year’s GSoC on “Optimization Passes”. I want to know what are we exploring(i.e. what potential passes to implement) in this project.

messages.text: Hi! I have a quick question. Is it recommended to include images in my proposal to illustrate my past projects, in Julia and otherwise?

elements.text: Hi! I have a quick question. Is it recommended to include images in my proposal to illustrate my past projects, in Julia and otherwise?

messages.text:
Hello everyone! My name is Marcello Politi and I am a final year Master student in Computer Science at the University of Tor Vergata in Rome, Italy. I have a strong passion for AI and Space technology. I have lately ended a 6 months internship at the European Space Agency and know I am currently enrolled as a research trainee at INRIA (Sophia-Antipolis Campus) where I am deepening my knowledge about Neural Network Pruning using Julia. I’ve seen some very interesting projects, but the ones which captured my attention were Scheduling algorithms for Distributed algorithms and some concerning Flux library. Could you give me some advice on how to prepare a strong application for those projects? 

I consider this experience very exciting and a great opportunity to boost our skills!

elements.text:

I have a strong passion for AI and Space technology. I have lately ended a 6 months internship at the European Space Agency and know I am currently enrolled as a research trainee at INRIA (Sophia-Antipolis Campus) where I am deepening my knowledge about Neural Network Pruning using Julia. I’ve seen some very interesting projects, but the ones which captured my attention were Scheduling algorithms for Distributed algorithms and some concerning Flux library. Could you give me some advice on how to prepare a strong application for those projects? 

I consider this experience very exciting and a great opportunity to boost our skills!

messages.text: General question about J/GSoC: How necessary or useful is it to maintain a blog over the course of the development period?

messages.text: If it isn't too much trouble, could some of the past GSoC/JSoC participants here also share the proposals they submitted? It might help other prospective candidates get a better idea of what their proposal should/shouldn't look like.

elements.text: If it isn't too much trouble, could some of the past GSoC/JSoC participants here also share the proposals they submitted? It might help other prospective candidates get a better idea of what their proposal should/shouldn't look like.

messages.text: You can find a lot of them in GSoC archive page, e.g, GSoC 2020 <https://summerofcode.withgoogle.com/archive/2020/organizations/6163109162516480/>

messages.text: Hey all, the JuliaCon Call for Proposals deadline is in 24 hours: <https://pretalx.com/juliacon2021/cfp|https://pretalx.com/juliacon2021/cfp> if you are interested to share your past GSoC/JSoC work or just something cool you are building (even if you are in the early stages) with Julia, please consider submitting a proposal. Can’t wait to see what you all have been working on. <!channel>

elements.text: Hey all, the JuliaCon Call for Proposals deadline is in 24 hours:
https://pretalx.com/juliacon2021/cfp

if you are interested to share your past GSoC/JSoC work or just something cool you are building (even if you are in the early stages) with Julia, please consider submitting a proposal. Can’t wait to see what you all have been working on.

messages.text: Hello friends - I'm JiangHang, a first-year graduate school student, majoring in computational mathematics in China. I want to sign up for the GSoC working for the Julia open-source library.  I would like to know how to find a mentor, and where's their information?

messages.text: The JuMP GSOC is handled by NumFocus which deals with other programming lagnuages too, in case a JuMP GSOC student doesn't get choosen for funds for GSOC will JSOC pick the student up if the application is good?

Hi! I'm considering applying for GSoC but was a bit unclear on the time commitment. I have an internship for this summer that I can't back out of but noticed that GSoC's website says projects require on avg 18 hours per week. Does anyone know if the Julia projects will follow suit? Is it worth applying and then discussing time commitments if I'm accepted?

elements.text: Hi! I'm considering applying for GSoC but was a bit unclear on the time commitment. I have an internship for this summer that I can't back out of but noticed that GSoC's website says projects require on avg 18 hours per week. Does anyone know if the Julia projects will follow suit? Is it worth applying and then discussing time commitments if I'm accepted?

messages.text: Hi Julian! Thanks for the interest. In the past, we’ve found that students with other commitments frequently end up failing GSOC. While the time commitment is less this year, I think this is still likely to be true. Our advice is therefore to enjoy your summer, and find side projects you enjoy, rather than pursuing it as a second job.

elements.text: Hi Julian! Thanks for the interest. In the past, we’ve found that students with other commitments frequently end up failing GSOC. While the time commitment is less this year, I think this is still likely to be true. Our advice is therefore to enjoy your summer, and find side projects you enjoy, rather than pursuing it as a second job.

messages.text: Hi, I want to apply for GSoC for  <https://julialang.org/jsoc/gsoc/diffeq/#numerical_differential_equations_projects_summer_of_code|Numerical Differential Equations - > <https://julialang.org/jsoc/gsoc/diffeq/#native_julia_ode_sde_dae_dde_and_spde_solvers|Native Julia ODE, SDE, DAE, DDE, and (S)PDE Solvers> and have a query related to that. Within this project it is mentioned that there are multiple possible families of methods to implement, for which students will be paired with researchers. So are we allowed to choose any of the methods or that would be decided from your side ?
